Executive Summary for Metcalf Energy Center, LLC

This document represents the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Metcalf Energy Center, LLC (MEC) located in San Jose, California. This document has been prepared in order to address the following issues:

* Acknowledge the construction and operation of a new source with processes subject to the RMP regulations and requirements.

MEC uses aqueous ammonia at a concentration of approximately 30% (by wt) and stores greater than 20,000 lbs making the site subject to both the California Accidental Release Program (CalARP) and the Federal RMP Program under 40 CFR 68. The site is not subject to either the OSHA or EPA Process Safety Management Regulations. The site has been determined to be a Program Level 2 facility.

The RMP addresses the Program 2 requirements of CalARP as adopted by the State of California as outlined in California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19. These requirements build upon the provisions of the ?general duty clause? of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, and the federal RMP Program 2 requirements in 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68, which require the following activities of all facilities which produce, process, store, or handle listed substances:

* identify hazards

* design and maintain a safe facility

* prevent releases

* minimize the consequences of releases.

The required approach to accomplishing the above, pursuant to the CalARP and Federal RMP regulations, is to have a documented RMP, which outlines the steps and procedures a facility will take to prevent and mitigate accidental releases. 

Pursuant to CCR Title 19, Section 2745.3, the following summary is given:

This RMP applies to the MEC facility located at:

1 Blanchard Rd.

San Jose, CA. 95013

UTM: N 4119623m, E 611409m



Facility Description and Regulated Substances

The Metcalf Energy Center (MEC) is a 600-megawatt (MW) (nominal output) natural-gas-fired combined cycle power plant, with a 230-kilovolt (kV) switchyard

feed into a newly constructed PG&E switchyard and approximately 200 feet of new 230-kV transmission line. A new transmission interconnection loops into the existing PG&E 230-kV Metcalf-Monta Vista No. 4 transmission line that passes near the northern boundary of the MEC site. No new transmission towers will be required. Natural gas for the facility is delivered via approximately one mile of new 16-inch pipeline that is connected to an existing PG&E transmission backbone pipeline that runs along the eastern side of U.S. 101. Recycled water for cooling is supplied by the South Bay Water Recycling Program (SBWR) and is delivered from a tap into SBWR?s existing main pipeline in eastern San Jose via a new 20inch, 7.3-mile pipeline. Industrial wastewater and sanitary sewer from the plant is transported from the plant via a 12inch (maximum) forced main installed in the same trench as the recycled water pipeline and connected to San Jose?s sewer system downstream of any system constraints. Process makeup water and domestic water is supplied from the city?s municipal water system (San Jose MUNI) via a 1.25-mile pipeline or from new onsite wells. This supply will also serve as a backup water supply for plant cooling. 

The site is located just west of Monterey Road, between Metcalf Road to the north and Bailey Road to the south.

Substance Used/Stored:    Aqueous Ammonia <=30% Solution (CAS# 1336-21-6)

                Ammonium Hydroxide, 15000 gallon tank



Facility SIC Code: 4911    Facility NAICS Code: 221112

The accidental release prevention and emergency action policies at the facility are delineated in Sections 4.0 and 14.0 respectively. A brief description of the prevention and emergency action policies is as follows.

Accident Prevention Program Policies and Elements

The accident prevention program is implemented through an established set of policies and programs including, but not limited to, the following:

* Inspection and maintenance program for all system equipment.

* Moni

toring of employee and contractor use of the system.

* Contractor Safety Program

* Emergency Action  Plan

* Lockout/Tagout Procedures and Program

* Hot Work Permit Program

* Confined Space Entry Program

* Employee Safety Training Program

* Compilation of substance information (MSDS)

* Incident investigation procedures

* Periodic compliance audits.

* Compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations.



Integral parts of the prevention program are the following plans:

Hazardous Materials Business Plan ? Injury and Illness Prevention Plan ? Spill Containment Control and Countermeasure Plan ? Hazardous Waste Storage and Handling Procedures ? Hazard Communication Program ? Fire Protection and Prevention Procedures ? Hearing Conservation Program ? Respiratory Conservation Program ? Electrical Safety Program ? Proposition 65 Compliance Program ? Forklift and Industrial Truck Program ? Welding, Cutting, and Brazing Safety Program

These plans are kept on site, for inspection during normal business hours.

Emergency Action Policies and Elements

The emergency action program is implemented through an established set of policies and programs including, but not limited to, the following:

* Establishment of criteria defining an emergency

* Staff training and responsibility assignments

* Emergency notification procedures (on and off-site)

* Evacuation procedures

* Written emergency action  procedures

* Coordination of emergency action with local authorities

* Incident investigation and follow-up procedures

The general accidental release prevention program is comprised of the following elements:

* Proper maintenance of all system equipment.

* Proper operation of all system equipment.

* Internal operating policies with respect to ammonia tank capacity.

* Comprehensive personnel training.

* A written emergency action plan.

* A written hazardous materials management plan.

* Documented safety procedures for employees and contractors.

* Inclus

ion of ammonia specific health, safety, and response data in the RMP.

The project is a new source and therefore has never experienced an accidental release of ammonia or any other hazardous substance in the last 5 years.

The emergency action plan and procedures (EAP) for MEC are similar in scope and detail to the EAP for similar Calpine power generation facilities (See section 14.0 and Appendix H). The Santa Clara County and/or City of San Jose Fire Departments will be the first responders in an ammonia emergency. MEC personnel will perform "awareness" duties only, which simply means that once the ammonia spill or release is discovered, MEC personnel will make the proper notifications and set the emergency procedures in motion. The fire departments will handle spill/release response and mitigation. In the event of a major release, MEC may join forces with the fire departments and State/County OES personnel in a "unified command effort" until the emergency has been mitigated.

Chemical Specific Prevention Elements

Chemical specific prevention measures are summarized as follows:

* Periodic inspection of ammonia tank, containment area, pumps, piping network, flow controllers, and injection grid.

* Monitoring of tank and system pressures and temperatures.

* Monitoring of unloading/delivery procedures.

* Installation and use of ammonia detector(s) in the main tank area.

* Installation and use of closed circuit cameras to view the ammonia storage area.

* Provide all required safety and response equipment.

* Provide a chemical specific training program.

* Access to the MEC facility site is controlled and fenced.

The piping and distribution network is equipped with a number of manual and automatic valves, which effectively limit the amount and duration of any accidental release. System pressures and flow rates will be monitored at the main plant control room console.  All liquid (aqueous ammonia) carrying piping is dual contained. Review of the P&IDs (Appendix C

) indicates that there are numerous pressure, temperature, and level indicator sensors, which will be reported directly to the distributed control system (DCS) for operator confirmation and action.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

    Presently, Calpine is operating and constructing a number of similar peaking and base loaded power generation facilities in California. Data developed from the operational experience at these facilities will be directly applied to the operation and safety aspects of the MEC facility. Operational and safety issues identified at any Calpine facility are immediately analyzed for applicability to other operational sites. Additionally, the following will be used to identify and track safety improvements at MEC.

* Completion of the initial PHA on January 10, 2005 for the MEC facility

* Required periodic updating of the PHA per the CalARP regulations

* Implementation and revision to safety and training procedures

* Completion of the seismic ?walk-down? inspection

* Completion of the CBO?s inspection of construction, i.e.,?ascertain compliance with applicable building and seismic codes



The facility will constantly strive for improved performance and reliability from all its processes. As specific process and safety improvements are identified they will be evaluated by staff for application and implementation.

Training

The facility staff, as well as Calpine corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of listed substances can be reduced and/or eliminated by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program.

The training program is comprised of the following:

* Initial employee training

* Periodic re-training and certification

* Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification 

* Refresher training

* Training records for eac

h employee



Maintenance



The maintenance element of the plant operations procedures ensures that new and modified equipment or processes are manufactured to meet process requirements, that they are installed correctly, and subsequently maintained in safe operating condition. 

The facility?s maintenance system is contained within the plant?s computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) known as MAXIMO and applicable maintenance manuals. The system manuals delineate such practices as:

* Equipment or process inspection techniques and frequency

* Preventative maintenance schedules

* Maintenance requirements and procedures

* History of maintenance

* Process identification, model numbers, and serial numbers

* Maintenance logs (who performed the maintenance, and information on the maintenance activity, etc.)

MAXIMO contains such records as:

* Written maintenance, testing, and inspection procedures and schedules.

* Maintenance training.

* Maintenance documentation.

* Deficiency correction procedures and documentation.



Pre-Startup Review



The pre-startup review program is not required to be documented in the RMP for Program 2 facilities. 



Compliance Audits



An essential element of the RMP program is the use of periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan. Compliance audits under the federal and state RMP regulations must be conducted, at a minimum of once every three years. The periodic compliance audit addresses the following:

* Implementation and comprehension of the current plan elements.

* Are plan revisions required.

* Does the plan adequately address all required RMP elements.

* Effectiveness of the current plan.

* Level of employee involvement.

* Management commitment to plan provisions.

The audit team is typically comprised of people knowledgeable of the process. The results of the compliance audit are communicated to all staff levels subsequent to completion of the audit.

Incident Investigation

Th

orough investigation of ?incidents? (any occurrence that results in or could result in catastrophic releases of aqueous ammonia) or ?near misses? (any situation where conditions existed under which an incident could have occurred, but did not) is another essential element of the RMP program. Incident investigations typically yield perspectives on equipment or process safety that are not normally apparent to plant operations and maintenance staff, such as:

* Incident ?causes? outside of the PHA scope.

* Was the facility response appropriate?

* Did the EAP function as designed?

* Did the EAP and RMP provide the necessary level of protection with respect to the offsite impacts?

* What changes need to be made to the RMP and EAP to ensure an appropriate response in the future?

Incident investigations pursuant to this RMP will be specific to the aqueous ammonia process system. The following data is typically gathered by the incident investigation team subsequent to the incident:

* Date and time of the ?incident? or ?near miss?

* Timeliness of incident report to the responding agency

* Timeliness of public awareness and/or evacuation measures

* Description of the incident or ?near miss?

* An evaluation of the events that resulted in the incident or ?near miss?

* Recommendations to prevent future occurrences of the incident

The incident investigation policy is delineated in the safety procedures. The investigation results, including the implementation of all recommendations, will be reviewed with facility staff whose job responsibilities are relevant to the findings. Copies of the investigation reports will be maintained on site for a minimum of five years, and will be used during the periodic PHA re-evaluations.



Employee Participation



The employee participation program is not required to be documented in the RMP for Program 2 facilities. 



Management of Change



The management of change program is not required to be documented in the RMP for Program 2

facilities. 



Contractor and Hot Work Program



The contractor safety and hot work permit programs are not required to be documented in the RMP for Program 2 facilities.



Release Scenario Data

The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the aqueous ammonia storage tank with full containment. This scenario results in the release of approximately 481.5 pounds of ammonia. The toxic endpoint value of 201 ppm is not exceeded at any location, i.e., on or offsite. Ammonia concentrations reach a peak value of approximately 43 ppm, with fence line concentrations on the order of 40 ppm. No offsite population impacts occur under this scenario, and the zone of impact is entirely within the facility boundary.

The alternate release scenario is the failure of the tank truck vessel unloading hose with the spill contents being discharged to the loading pad surface, which drains to an underground sump. This scenario results in the release of approximately 14.9 pounds of ammonia. The toxic endpoint value of 201 ppm is never reached, and fence line concentrations are on the order of 6 ppm. Therefore this scenario will not affect any offsite populations, and the zone of impact is entirely within the MEC facility boundary.

In addition to running OCA scenarios for the CalARP and federal toxic endpoint value, the worst case and alternate release scenarios were also evaluated for the California Energy Commission COC HAZ-4 value of 75 ppm (30 minute averaging time). The COC-HAZ-4 worst case release shows a fence line concentration of approximately 74-75 ppm, while the COC-HAZ-4 alternate release scenario shows a fence line concentration of approximately 10 ppm. The zone of impact for both scenarios is within the property boundary. See section 16 for OCA data summaries.
